block.p: Stocks Trade in Vietnam, But Confusion Takes Over With just two stocks, two hours and $5,000 in trades, Communist-governed Vietnam opened its first stock exchange for business and took the first faltering steps into the uncertain world of free markets.

Hopeful investors packed into the three brokerage offices taking orders for the shares to watch the market's birth on electronic boards. But curiosity and excitement quickly turned into confusion and disappointment, when minutes before the Ho Chi Minh City Securities Trading Center opened, the government imposed a ceiling on bids that invalidated many people's orders -- some of which were more than 50 percent above the government's artificially imposed prices. [Page C2.]

Nortel to Buy Alteon for $7.8 Billion Nortel Networks agreed to acquire Alteon WebSystems, which makes equipment that improves the efficiency of Web server computers, for $7.8 billion in stock. Earlier this week Nortel ended discussions to combine its optical components unit with that of Corning. Shares of Nortel fell $5.125, to $73, after setting a 52-week high of $87 on Tuesday. [C4.]

U.S. Faults Mexican Phone Market The Clinton administration took the first steps toward filing a formal complaint against Mexico for failing to ensure open competition in its $12 billion telecommunications market, just weeks before Mexico's president-elect, Vicente Fox, is scheduled to make his first visit to Washington to discuss commercial relations with the United States. [C2.]

A New Chief Executive at iVillage Candice Carpenter, the founder of iVillage, the Web site focused on topics of interest to women, has stepped down as chief executive and named Doug McCormick, who joined the company in April as president. Ms. Carpenter, who will remain chairwoman, will focus on strategy and international expansion. [C3.]

NBC Executive Promoted at G.E. Robert C. Wright, the longtime president of NBC, was named to the additional post of vice chairman of General Electric. Mr. Wright, left, is not considered a possible successor to the G.E. chairman, John F. Welch Jr., who is scheduled to retire in nine months, but industry executives said the move emphasizes the importance of NBC in G.E.'s future. [C14.]

Interpool Buys Rail Cargo Company Interpool, a unit of the Dutch insurer Aegon that leases cargo containers, said that it had agreed to buy a rival, Transamerica Leasing Inc., for about $675 million to add Transamerica's strength in rail cargo to its own operations in maritime shipping. [C3.]

Industrial Output Increases in Japan Japan's economic recovery seems to be continuing, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Industrial output rose 1.7 percent in June from the previous month, bringing output growth in the April-June quarter to 1.6 percent, the fourth consecutive quarterly increase. [C2.]

Hyundai Unit Seeks Emergency Loan Hyundai Engineering and Construction, a subsidiary of South Korea's largest business conglomerate, the Hyundai Group, requested emergency loans from creditors to repay about $161 million in loans. The move raises concerns that another huge bankruptcy may be in the making and comes a year after the Daewoo Group collapsed under debts estimated at $80 billion. [C2.]

Viacom Expects $1.5 Billion Charge Viacom will take charges of about $1.5 billion in the second quarter for costs related to buying CBS and for new film accounting rules, according to a recent filing and analysts' estimates. [C14.]
